column4: to use all of someone's mental or physical energy :to tire out or wear out (someone) completely
column5: If you keep working these long hours, you're just going to exhaust yourself. = Working these long hours will just exhaust you.

column4: cruel and unfair treatment by people with power over others
column5: The refugees were fleeing tyranny.

column4: currently popular
column5: fashionable clothes [=clothes that are popular; clothes that are in fashion]

column4: a belief that something is true even though it has not been proved often + that
column5: The presumption is that the thief had a key to the store.

column4: to cause (someone) to be likely to do or have something + to or toward
column5: His upbringing disposes him to question authority.

column4: honor or respect that is felt for or shown to (someone or something)
column5: Her poems are treated with reverence by other poets.

column4: the quality of people who have too much pride in their own appearance, abilities, achievements, etc. :the quality of being vain
column5: The handsome actor's vanity was well-known.

column4: to argue or state (something) in a strong and definite way
column5: These people contend that they have earned the right to the land.

column4: not capable of dying :living forever
column5: the immortal soul

column4: to prepare and use (soil) for growing plants
column5: Prehistoric peoples settled the area and began to cultivate the land.

column4: to officially make (a law) no longer valid
column5: The state legislature eventually repealed [=rescinded] the tax (law).

column4: to keep (someone or something) within limits :to prevent (someone or something) from going beyond a particular limit, area, etc. usually + to
column5: Please confine [=restrict, limit] your comments to 200 words.

column4: to teach (someone) a subject, skill, etc. usually + in or on
column5: His friend instructed him in English.

column4: to make (something) impossible :to prevent (something) from happening
column5: She suffered an injury that precluded the possibility of an athletic career.

column4: on the thing that has been mentioned
column5: The highway and structures thereon are being repaired.

column4: to speak or read (something) to a person who writes it down or to a machine that records it
column5: She's dictating a letter to her secretary.

column4: to cause the occurrence of (a feeling or action) :to make (something) happen
column5: His remarks provoked both tears and laughter.

column4: extremely good or enjoyable :wonderful
column5: We had a marvelous time at the party.

column4: extremely or unusually large :gigantic
column5: a monstrous billboard

column4: to happen, go, or come before (something or someone)
column5: Riots preceded the civil war.

column4: to say the opposite of (something that someone else has said) :to deny the truth of (something)
column5: contradict a rumor

column4: to begin
column5: The festivities will commence with a parade.

column4: people in the future
column5: Posterity will remember her as a woman of courage and integrity.

column4: to hold (something) back
column5: You can withhold the fee until the work is complete. [=you can wait to pay the fee until after the work is complete]

column4: relating to religious or political sects and the differences between them
column5: sectarian movements

column4: a formal quality
column5: Her use of old-fashioned language lends an air of formality to her writing.

column4: to crush or break (something) into very small pieces by rubbing it against a rough surface or using a special machine
column5: Grind (up) the coffee beans into a fine powder.

column4: to supply (something) with light :to shine light on (something)
column5: Candles illuminate [=light] the church.

column4: very large :containing a lot of space
column5: a voluminous room

column4: the study of family history
column5: an expert in genealogy

column4: great and often wild or uncontrolled activity
column5: the buying frenzy just before Christmas

column4: to dislike (something or someone) very much
column5: He despises [=hates, loathes] pop music.

column4: not capable of being wrong or making mistakes :not fallible
column5: I never claimed to be infallible.

column4: causing trouble or problems :not convenient
column5: The restaurant is in an inconvenient location.

column4: very large in amount or number
column5: The storm produced a copious amount of rain.

column4: a word or phrase that describes a person or thing
column5: His charitable works have earned him the epithet ‰ÛÏMr. Philanthropy.‰Ûù

column4: having complete or unlimited power :all-powerful
column5: omnipotent gods

column4: very shocking or bad
column5: People there are living in horrid conditions.

column4: a major road that you must pay to use
column5: the Massachusetts Turnpike

column4: a deep hole or opening in the surface of the earth :gorge
column5: Leaders tried to bridge a chasm [=split, divide] between the two religious groups.

column4: to destroy (something or someone) completely
column5: Bombs annihilated the city.

column4: ability or willingness to believe something
column5: Although most of the book is believable, its ending tests/strains credulity. [=its ending is difficult to believe; its ending does not seem true or possible]

column4: to make (someone) impatient, angry, or annoyed
column5: It's his arrogance that really irritates me.

column4: to take and keep (something, such as power) in a forceful or violent way and especially without the right to do so
column5: Some people have accused city council members of trying to usurp the mayor's power.

column4: sed to describe someone (such as a person who often gets drunk) whose way of living is considered morally wrong
column5: a dissolute drunk

column4: a person who has recently begun an activity, become successful, etc., and who does not show proper respect for older and more experienced people
column5: a young upstart from Harvard who thinks he knows more than the boss

column4: unable to read or write :illiterate
column5: unlettered peasants

column4: a person who is not famous or important
column5: She quickly went from being a nonentity [=nobody] to being one of the most famous women in the country.

column4: to put (someone) in a usually unpleasant place or situation + to
column5: Survivors described how they were consigned to labor camps.

column4: to belong to or be connected or related to something :pertain
column5: the rights and privileges that appertain to marriage
